description: Netdata dashboards for Grafana via Prometheus.

panels.description: System uptime
panels.title: Uptime

panels.description: Total number of CPU cores
panels.title: CPU Cores

panels.description: Total RAM
panels.title: Total RAM

panels.description: Total SWAP
panels.title: Total SWAP

panels.description: Total RootFS
panels.title: Total Root FS

panels.description: Total RootFS
panels.title: Total Data FS

panels.description: Busy state of all CPU cores together
panels.title: CPU Busy

panels.description: Non available RAM memory
panels.title: Used RAM Memory

panels.description: Used Swap
panels.title: Used SWAP

panels.description: Used Root FS
panels.title: Used Root FS

panels.description: Used Root FS
panels.title: Used Data FS

panels.description:
Total CPU utilization (all cores). 100% here means there is no CPU idle time at all. You can get per core usage at the _CPUs_ section and per application usage at the _Applications monitoring_ section.

Keep an eye on **iowait**. If it is constantly high, your disks are a bottleneck and they slow your system down.

An important metric worth monitoring, is **softirq**. A constantly high percentage of softirq may indicate network driver issues.
panels.title: Total CPU utilization

panels.description:
Current system load, i.e. the number of processes using CPU or waiting for system resources (usually CPU and disk). The 3 metrics refer to 1, 5 and 15 minute averages. The system calculates this once every 5 seconds.

For more information check this [Wikipedia article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Load_(computing))
panels.title: System load average

panels.description:
Total Disk I/O, for all physical disks. You can get detailed information about each disk at the _Disks_ section and per application Disk usage at the _Applications Monitoring_ section.

Physical are all the disks that are listed in `/sys/block`, but do not exist in `/sys/devices/virtual/block`.
panels.title: Disk I/O

panels.description: Memory paged from/to disk. This is usually the total disk I/O of the system.
panels.title: Memory paged from/to disk

panels.description: System Random Access Memory (i.e. physical memory) usage.
panels.title: System RAM

panels.description: System swap memory usage. Swap space is used when the amount of physical memory (RAM) is full. When the system needs more memory resources and the RAM is full, inactive pages in memory are moved to the swap space (usually a disk, a disk partition or a file).
panels.title: System swap

panels.description: Total Swap I/O. (netdata measures both `in` and `out`. If either of them is not shown in the chart, it is because it is zero - you can change the page settings to always render all the available dimensions on all charts).
panels.title: Swap I/O

panels.description: Total IPv4 Traffic.
panels.title: Network bandwidth

panels.description: System processes. **Running** are the processes in the CPU. **Blocked** are processes that are willing to enter the CPU, but they cannot, e.g. because they wait for disk activity.
panels.title: System processes

panels.description: Number of new processes created.
panels.title: Started processes

panels.description: All system processes.
panels.title: System active processes

panels.description: [Context Switches](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context_switch), is the switching of the CPU from one process, task or thread to another. If there are many processes or threads willing to execute and very few CPU cores available to handle them, the system is making more context switching to balance the CPU resources among them. The whole process is computationally intensive. The more the context switches, the slower the system gets.
panels.title: CPU context switches

panels.description: Idle jitter is calculated by netdata. A thread is spawned that requests to sleep for a few microseconds. When the system wakes it up, it measures how many microseconds have passed. The difference between the requested and the actual duration of the sleep, is the idle jitter. This number is useful in real-time environments, where CPU jitter can affect the quality of the service (like VoIP media gateways).
panels.title: CPU idle jitter

panels.description: Total number of CPU interrupts. Check the system interrupts graph that gives more detail about each interrupt and also the _CPUs_ section where interrupts are analyzed per CPU core.
panels.title: CPU interrupts

panels.description: CPU interrupts in detail. At the _CPUs_ section, interrupts are analyzed per CPU core.
panels.title: System interrupts

panels.description: CPU softirqs in detail. At the _CPUs_ section, softirqs are analyzed per CPU core.
panels.title: System softirqs

title: Netdata Overview
